Description: Brass lamp in the form of a standing female panther, with a long, octagonal-sectioned nozzle extending from the chest, terminating in an angular tip with a circular wick-hole. The animal is harnessed and wears a collar with circular pendants. The collar forms the rim of the filling-hole, and is stepped and hinged for a lid, which was formed by the panther's head, now lost. The straps of the harness and the collar are decorated with lozenges and transverse grooves. Suspension-loops (one lost) emerge from the harness on each side of the body; a third suspension-loop may have been placed on the back of the animal, just above the tail, where a cut down patch occurs. A large rectangular repair patch is let into the underside of the body, between the teats. Hinged lid missing. Surface colouration: patchy brown, dark and light green.
Curator's comments: Compare Torok, L., 1988. ‘Late antique Nubia : history and archaeology of the southern neighbor of Egypt in the 4th-6th c. A. D’. Budapest : Archaeological Institute of The Hungarian Academy of Sciences, pl. XXVII, from Egypt, and perhaps Wulff, O., 1909. ‘Altchristliche und mittelalterliche byzantinische und italienische Bildwerke’ I. Berlin : Reimer, No. 777, from Egypt, and also Sotheby 'Sale Catalogue' 11 July 1988, Lot 154, all in the form of a lion. Compare tooVermeule C. C., and Comstock, M. B., 1988. ‘Sculpture in Stone and Bronze’ Boston : Boston Museum of Fine Art, No. 114, from Egypt, where a Coptic or medieval Islamic date is considered; also the brass lion-lamp from Sardis ('American Journal of Archaeology' 78, 1974, pls. 63-4; Waldbaum, J.C., 1983. ‘Metalwork from Sardis : the finds through 1974’. Cambridge, Mass. : Harvard University Press, pl. 40, 618) found in an early seventh-century context, but possibly to be dated earlier; also a lion lamp in Catania: Libertini, G., 1930. ‘Il Museo Biscari’. Milan : Roma, Casa editrice e'arte Bestetti e Tumminelli, 525. Compare perhaps Eton College, Myers Collection, No. 1685, from Egypt, in the form of a stallion (but the nozzle-shape points possibly to a Hellenistic date). None of these has a hinged head.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (3592)
Xanthopoulou 2010 / Les lampes en bronze à l’époque paléochrétienne (LA 13.004) (listed as inv. 1909,0616.10)
Condition: incomplete - lid lost. Surface coloration: patchy brown, dark and light green.
